values.category: I know we can make websites just with HTML/CSS/Javascript, but there's gotta be some ways to make default, reusable user interfaces

libraries.name: Bootstrap
libraries.description: gives default CSS styling and JS interactions out of the box, as well as optimizes for responsiveness

libraries.name: Foundation
libraries.description: well, does the same thing as Bootstrap, you can pick :D

libraries.name: Material Design Lite
libraries.description: does the same thing as the two above, but for the Google lovers out there, you'll be able to do Material Design

values.category: Cool, but not I have some structured JSON data I want to display. You got any frameworks for that?

libraries.name: jQuery
libraries.description: makes Javascript a lot more concise and easier to write, uses the dollar sign everywhere

libraries.name: Mustache
libraries.description: a super super barebones templating language that uses, you guessed it, a curly brace which sideways looks like a mustache, might be a little hard to start up

libraries.name: Angular
libraries.description: provides a ton of data-binding mechanisms and ways to create your own HTML tags to represent different data entities, recommended if you are going to eventually hook up a backend

values.category: Ok, cool, I think I got a handle on how to do front-end + data-binding. I want to start developing a backend. Any recommendations?

libraries.name: Flask
libraries.description: a simple Python framework for setting a web application, they also provide some front-end tooling for templating, a lot more beginner friendly

libraries.name: Node/ExpressJS
libraries.description: a way to develop a backend using just Javascript, because why not? you don't have to switch languages now! more things you'll have to put together, recommended after some experience

values.category: Ok, cool, now I got a frontend and a backend setup for myself. I need a database. Waddaya recommend?

libraries.name: MySQL
libraries.description: a good starter to understanding how to structure data in the form of tables, easiest to learn and get started on

libraries.name: Firebase
libraries.description: a JSON-based datastore that integrates with many Javascript frameworks, also provides real-time updates, easy to set up

libraries.name: mLab
libraries.description: allows you to spin up a MongoDB instance in the cloud, no installation required, if you're up for playing around with NoSQL databases

values.category: Ok, but now I want to serve my website. I want a URL!

libraries.name: Github Pages
libraries.description: a simple way to publish your own website straight from Github, recommended for front-end only projects

libraries.name: Heroku
libraries.description: an easy way to push a full-stack web application live, whether it be Flask-based, Node-based, etc.

libraries.name: DigitalOcean
libraries.description: a barebones service that allows you to start up virtual machines to host and start your web server on, advanced set up though because you have to do everything yourself

values.category: But what if I don't want to do web development? Mobile forever!

libraries.name: Android Studio
libraries.description: Google's official IDE for Android development, if you got an Android phone, you can also load your app onto your phone to test it out, requires Java

libraries.name: XCode
libraries.description: Apple's official IDE for iOS and Mac development, comes with built-in emulators for iPhones of all generations, requires a Mac

values.category: Mmm, none of those suit my fancy. What about hardware?

libraries.name: Raspberry Pi
libraries.description: a compact computer that comes with many different circuit parts too

libraries.name: Arduino
libraries.description: a compact circuit-board that allows you to prototype, also comes with a software package specifically for Arduino projects

values.category: I really want to get my feet wet in data. Are there APIs or data sources you recommend?

libraries.name: Awesome JSON Datasets
libraries.description: an open-source list of different APIs available to get data from, ranging from weather to social media to financial data

libraries.name: US Government Open Data
libraries.description: the US Government's hub for datasets related to anything government-related, ranging from education to agriculture

libraries.name: Academic Torrents
libraries.description: 15.2 TB of research data available for you to play with

values.category: What are some data visualization libraries that can help me make sense of so much data?

libraries.name: Matplotlib
libraries.description: this is the default library used for scientific computing and data visualization in Python, many libraries built on top of this

libraries.name: d3js (and its variants)
libraries.description: this is the default data visualization library for Javascript to display visualizations on the web, many libraries built on top of this
